5.21.text:
A fantastic lizard native to Australia and
Southeast Asia is the Blue-Tongued Skink.

11.03.text:
This is one of those in-betweener animals
that almost looks snakelike.

15.12.text:
It's evolved to have little, almost insignificant
arms and legs.

19.49.text: It's really a defenseless creature in nature.

22.97.text:
Of the 3,000 plus skinks in the world, I believe
over 900 of them are different types of skinks.

29.00.text:

that elongated body, but only one has got

37.14.text:

41.24.text:
area, but they all use that tongue for the
same reason.

46.52.text:
And that is to scare off or ward off a potential
predator.

52.91.text: It's almost fossorial in its approach to life.

55.45.text: It stays just underneath the ground.

57.46.text:

leaf litter, and it stays there kind of a

62.46.text:

really doesn't have the ability to run very

72.54.text: fast due to those arms and legs.

76.36.text: It does not climb trees at all.

It has no ability to do that because of those
arms and legs and its body shape.

81.52.text:
He swims a little bit, but he's not winning
any races getting away from anyone.

85.44.text: He's kind of toast if somebody finds him.

87.30.text: So, what did nature give him?

88.85.text: They gave him that amazing tongue.

90.89.text:
And oftentimes, in the animal kingdom, color
means watch out.

97.76.text:
And what he'll do is open his mouth and wag
his tongue back and forth in an attempt to

103.04.text: scare off the predators trying to eat him.

105.75.text:
Works sometimes, but it's not the greatest
method of scaring someone away.

109.75.text:
If someone's pointing a gun at you, you don't
stick your tongue out at them.

111.73.text: It's not going to work, right?

113.67.text: You want to have an ability to run.

115.49.text: But the Blue-Tongued Skink doesn't do that.

So, oftentimes he becomes prey, not the predator,
to a larger animal.

So another incredible fact about a really
